22 oz bottle.  In a night that included ALOT of big time beers this was a great surprise to me.  Dark brown pour with thin ring around the rim.  Nose of bourbon, dark fruits and toffee/caramel.  Taste was certainly bourbon but not overpowering.  Nice sweet malty notes.  At less than $8 a bomber this does not dissapoint.

Shared by GOGRANDE. You rock my friend. Dark creamy pour with a thin head. Boozy aroma, sweet with  hints of oak and burnt sugar. Flavor was a little sweet for my liking, a lot of malt and boozieness.
Bottle thanks to jjfoodie.  Black with a cream head.  Nose is rye, wood, chocolate, roasted malts, smoke, delicious.  Great palate, flavor matches the nose dead on.

(22oz bottle thanks to JJFoodie) rich deep brown pour, thick creamy dark tan head. Nose of raisin, vanilla, bourbon, big and in your face. taste of bourbon, toasty raisin, vanilla. Milk chocolate,Caramel,  rich and decadent! creamy, awesome linger, vanilla on the palate. Great carbonation.
Smells great. Looks dark and thick. Palate is casky with a chewy texture almost. Smoky, woody tones. Molasses? Good, but more bitter than I expected.
Lots of earth in this one. I tasted some bark and raisins. Very dark and fizzy. Nothing for head. It had a hayish taste to it.

Pours very dark dark brown with a light crimson hue to the light and a dense tan head.  The aroma has raisins, pumpernickel bread, dark caramel, roasted malt, some bourbon, vanilla and rich cream.  Medium thick body that has lots of soft frothy carbonation.  The flavor starts with a lot of whats on the aroma, but there is also a berry/red fruit type of taste in there as well.  This is quite complex and the barrel aging seems to help bring things together - the bourbon, oak and vanilla traits are there, but they dont dominate and the intriguing (and hard to describe) malt character shines as well.  The hops are really in the background, but that may be because Ive been holding onto this for a while.  Either way its a very enjoyable beer that exceed my expectations.  Nice job.

3rd beeer of the night. Very dark mahogany ale with a small, creamy head. Decent retention. The aroma is of caramel, oak, maple syrup and chocolate with just enough rye whiskey to enhance. Full-bodied and oily with mild carbonation. The flavor is mainly of caramel and toffee with a little hop bitterness and a hint of rye whiskey.  Warming finish.  I was still feeling this one in the morning.

Outrageous concept - years 8 to 14 of their Jewbelation ales, all mixed together!  I have had some other mixed releases in the last few months, good ones from Sierra Nevada and Stone, but none with this many brews in the blend.  Could this be a case of overkill?  VJ has a rich, bready flavor with some cola sweetness, rye, brownies, and nuts.  The funky aroma has coffee and whiskey notes.  It is nicely hopped, and it gets sharper and hoppier towards the bottom of the bottle.  This is good but a little muddy - a little too much or too little of something or other.  Still good tho, and plenty big.

HOLLY CRAP!!!! The beer smells and taste phenomenal, MY MIND JUST GOT BLOWEN! Looks dark woody brown with a normal looking cap floating on top. Smells like a mild version of all the other jewbilation beers but has the loveliness of vanilla and oak from the barrel aging. Some alcohol is in the nose but its smooth, the rye is really starting to dominate the aroma in a really good way. Reminds me of my dad drinking Crown Royal and coke when I was a kid.  YUM YUM.  First sip just completely warmed my stomach  but a very smooth way.. Wow massive rye flavor, tons of vanilla and oak.  Malts are dark and yummy, prunes, cherry, red wine (hard to find) and just the mildest hints of coffee some soya sauce. I love this beer! Half beer, half crown royal all good!! yum beer I like a lot, I want more.

Aroma is - WOO WEE, strong, malty, woody, with an alcohol underpinning and yeasty and floral hints. It pours a pretty chocolaty brown that is opaque save at the edges, with a fairly good beige head. Flavor is - not for the faint of heart! Quite strong, it is woody, malty, a little honey sweet, slightly fruity, slightly nutty, with a good alcohol edge. Texture is smooth and edgy, leaving a woody and tingly finish.
Bottle. Aroma- Lots of dark fruit, smoke, tobacco, leather, molasses, with not too much whiskey. Taste is nice, sweet, smoke, some alcohol bite. Very nice beer.

When I saw this bottle I was very excited to try it.  It sounds like a very cool concept.  Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights and a tan head.  Nose is whiskey, booze, some vanilla, chocolate, some dates, maybe plums, raisins, and a bit of wood.  Flavor is similar with a nice mouthfeel.  I get chocolate, then whiskey, a hint of vanilla, slight coconut, background spices, then rounds out with booze, chocolate, whiskey, and dates/ fruit.  Enjoyable whiskey quality that stays toward the middle - not quiet, but certainly not overpowering.

Pours dark. Sticky good foam. Lasts and lasts. Smells of sweet vanilla, oak, coffee, chocolate. Tastes creamy rich. Irish coffee, iced coffee, baileys. Bourbon as well. Tastey. Thick but very good. Not overkill. Lots of malt with good complexity. May be too rich for some. Not for me.

The Dan Journal #460. Tasted 3/28/11. 22oz bomber, Bottling date 12/1/10. Batch No. 002/ Case 892. Pours dark brown with an opaque body. Spotty, moldy tan head. Huge aromas of the woody barrel aging plus raisins and a touch musty basement. Nice caramel, vanilla, dark chocolate and fudge aromas round out the olfactory. Really nice nose! Full bodied with a really nice palate. The creamy vanilla, barrel note is in the forefront and is definitely the most noticeable aspect of the palate. Theres a good bitterness from both the hops and the effervescence. Flavors of bittersweet chocolate and maple syrup. A faint burn and a very cloying finish. Good malty notes with a viscous and thick body. Very well blended, but its still a really big beer! Great complexity!

very malty aroma, with cloves, roasted grain, oak, and cloying sweetness.
pours an almost opaque brown with small fine tan head.
flavor is sweet also, but only slightly cloying, with a caramelly and malty feeling all around.
nice medium-heavy body, rich and with a long sweet finish.
this seems to be somewhere between a strong and a stout, its very roasty.

Pour dark brown with tan head nice lace. Aroma vanilla, oak, bourbon, malt, caramel, roast, wood, maple, dark fruit. Taste roasty, dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, wood, oak, caramel, whiskey, maple, tannin. MF full body slightly creamy nice carb. Overall super complex and all over but very good at the same time would highly recommend.

Appearance: pours the color of old woods dark and mysterious. Lovely tan head lingers as a solid blanket while lace crawls up the sides of my glass. Swirls with lace and puff.

Nose: vanillin and caramel supple, soft, and sublime. Maple and meaty dark fruits: prunes and figs. Smoky in the back with a hint of ash and white hot charcoal.

Palate: clean procession of flavors with medium weight. Vanillin and caramel first, ash and charcoal in the middle and meaty dark fruits in the end. Delightful finish. Lingering prunes and plums in the back of throat. Tannic and tart along the bottom and sides of mouth, cheeks tingle. Burnt wood and smoke. Vanilla and caramel permeates subtly and smoothly from first quaff to last. Chest is warm. Fire pits, smoky and burnt, woody.

Final Thoughts: wow and wow. Once more I love beer that is touched by wood. I enjoyed all the Jewbelations from HeBrew but if I had to choose, Vertical was the overall winner.

Bottle courtesy of bmanning. Served in a tulip.

Pours near black with a thin tan head a bubbly collar. The nose is a bit plain with only a bit of slight barrel character and roast. The taste brings more barrel notes as well as some of the rye whiskey and a slight amount of roasted malt. There is some chocolate character there as well. The mouthfeel is really quite smooth ad integrates the whiskey quite well. Medium to full body. Drinkability is nice and certainly enhanced by the smooth feel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-20-2010

What a fine beer, shared a bomber (Batch 002/892, December 2010) with Ferdinand Hepperle and Barbara Nytes-Baron in North Bergen. I cant top the great descriptions here from fans like Ugsmash and Tmoney99, but the adjectives are just right: vinous, caramel, and molasses sweetness, for example. The color, the aroma, the tastes (complex and smooth)  make this recipe a big winner. And approved by a rabbi!

22. A fun, big beast. Pours black with a dense creamy burnt tan head. Webby lace hanging around. Big barrely nose with some dark fruits and earthy malts on the nose...interesting result. Maybe too much in the way of liquor barrel fumes, but the rye doesnt overpower other than that hot bite. Creamy medium body, surprisingly light. Earthy rye, caramel, figs, and an overall sense of candied fruit on the mid-palate. A little bitey on the finish. Really a nice effort...not necessarily in terms of subtley or complexity, but in overall terms of how fun it is to drink. Hits the spot. But, then, its well-known that I am a huge rye whore, so there it is.

Mix of grape curranty juice and soysaucy rye aroma black with light tan thin head taste is grape curranty taste with some slight barrel taste along with some coffee roasty tastes as well, great beer very very complex between the deep juicy flavors and the roasty malt taste

Bomber, Batch 002, bottled 12/1/2010. Deep chestnut with a lasting creamy foam. Nose is raisin, oak, merlot, and caramel.  Taste is vanilla, whiskey, caramel, prune, chocolate. Heavy body is sweetish, but dried by the oak and alcohol.
Unbalanced.  The barrel does a bit to mask the craziness of this brew but it just aint for me.boozy

Batch 002 / 892 cases. Bottled 12/1/2010. Poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Black color or at least pretty damn close to black. Two and a half fingers of creamy/frothy light brown head. The first two fingers falls rather quickly, but the last half sticks around a good while. Some nonuniform lacing.

3.5 S: The nose is mellow, too mellow for its own damn good. The rye whiskey is the most apparent aroma and is the only component with any power. Chocolate and caramel lead the malts with vanilla and peachy fruitiness from the barrel. Not bad by any means, but the underlying cuvee desparately needs a boost in strength.

3.0 T: The taste is pretty mediocre. The flavors dont mesh well together. The whiskey dominates with the rye giving a earthy spiciness. A lot of vanilla, melon, and oak flavor as well with a touch of astringency. Unfortunately, the base beers cant quite blend well with the whiskey and barrel flavors. Chocolate, caramel, and toffee are there in plentiful proportions. Prune, fig, molasses, and brown sugar. Not enough roastiness to balance everything out.

3.5 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. A bit chewier than I like, but otherwise smooth. Some booze on finish.

2.5 D: This has the problem of the barrel dominating the beer and the beer itself being too sweet. I would have liked this better if it were dried out a bit and only half of it barrel aged.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-19-2011 02:14:46

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy dark brown with a brown head that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma is full of dark grains with some dark fruits and a bit of a spice and rye whiskey backing. Flavor started with dark grains and a bit of toffee and was joined by some dark fruit with the rye whiskey coming out in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a murky dark brown with a very sticky frothy beige head.  Aroma is big coconut, molasses, and alcohol.  Flavor follows, rye, big and sticky tasting, sugary, big coconut, syrupy, molasses, bit of whiskey, dark caramel, love the barrel but the beer seems too sweet, rich.  Body is very fluffy and sticky.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured a dark brown color with an average creamy brown head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted caramel malt, caramel, complex wood and alcohol aroma. Medium to heavy bittersweet toasted malt flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet and small alcohol bite finish of moderate to long duration. Full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. This is a standout beer.

Batch 002/892 brewed 12-1-10: pours a dark stoutish brown, black  with a foamy tan head. sticky lacing. notes of vanilla, rye malts, oak, roasted coconut, whiskey booze on the nose. really well balanced as theres a milky texture and richness that makes these fairly easy drinking for the alcohol level. chocolate and whiskey on the finish. well crafted

Bomber.  Poured a lovely shade of deep garnet with a fine cap of toffee head.  The aroma picked up sweet whiskey and vanilla character over vinous, caramel, and molasses sweetness.. definitely some hop presence around, but it was muddled and hung out in the background behind the malts and barrel.. syrupy and really enjoyable.  The flavor found more dark fruity sweetness at the core than anything else, with lesser molasses and sweet whiskey notes behind.. vanilla, fruity bitterness, and a touch of pine extended outward.. warm sugars, more whiskey barrel, and an ideal level of heat on the long finish.. felt it into the belly.  Medium-plus bodied and sweet overall on the palate.. syrupy and delicious.. I wasnt expecting to love this, but it was mighty tasty!

Bottle shared by the legendary footbalm at the going away party for our friends 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, dark fruits, rye and woody 
Taste: Roasted malts, woody, rye and vanilla 
A very nice beer, smooth and easy drinkability

Bottle. Essentially opaque black. Short, dense, foamy beige head. Aroma is toasted coconut, oak, sweet malt, caramel, vanilla, molasses and alcohol. Taste is big toasted coconut, vanilla, molasses, oak, alcohol, dark fruit, and whiskey. Body is thick and sticky with dense carbonation and alcohol warmth. Finishes with more coconut and vanilla, chewy caramel, roasted malt, dark fruit, oak, molasses and alcohol notes. Very tasty stuff!

Bomber thanks to Ibrew2or3. Pours a very dark color that at first appears to be black but is actually more of a purple, with a small white head. The aroma is massive rye whiskey and loads of sweet fruity malt, some berries. A very nice flavor; toasted malts, rich sweet hops, a light bitterness, a very nice barrel treatment, loads of whiskey but not that much heat. Sweet, berries and hops, this is nice. Id love to have seen a proper blend of the older vintages in. Still, very nice, a excellent brew in fact.

Pours fairly close to black like the other jewbelations except with a slight red hue around the edges. Thin tan head that fades quickly but leaves a nice ring. Aroma is of malty goodness - dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, smoke. Flavor is very complex, I can pick out vanilla, oak, cherries, chocolate. Hides the alcohol very well also.

I am a huge fan of the Hebrew Jewbelation beers and this one is my favorite by far. Great tasting, I wish I could get more of it as I have only found it in the limited release "Beer Menorah" gift set.

Bottle. Boozy whiskey barrel smell seemed to be the only set back on this beer.  The taste was awesome. Very complex, well balanced.  Reminds me of aged beers out of the cellar.  The dark fruits blend well with the vanilla, whiskey, and oak flavors.  Alcohol is noticeable, but not over the top.  Wish I could find another bottle, this stuff is great.

Bottle, from the Vertical Jewbelation Pack. Pours clear black, with a red/brown flash. Thin pale tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is big rye barrel, big red and black fruit, tobacco, leather, smoke. Flavours of rye, dark fruit, tobacco, barrel-vanilla. Fabulous stuff.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with frothy tan edging.  Nose is chocolate, dark berries, oak and whiskey.  Hot and tingly with a warming creamy finish.  Taste is caramel, elderberry, dark chocolate and candied lime peel.  Grassy with whiskey.  Comes together quite nicely.

22oz. bottle served in a snifter. Poured a deep brown with a quickly dissipating tan head. Big aroma of whiskey, vanilla, chocolate and a little alcohol. Full bodied, rich and smooth mouthfeel. Tons of toffee and chocolate in the flavor. Not as much whiskey as you would have expected from the aroma, but it is there. Enough hops to balance the malt, but not a lot of hop bitterness. Long dry finish of chocolate.

After the 13 and 14, I expected a big, boozy mess, but this was very nice.
Poured dark brown, dark fruits, brown sugar, wood, little nutty, little rye.

Deep mahogany color with a dense, creamy tan head.  Nice whiskey and vanilla aroma.  Delicious vanilla infused flavor of caramel candies and pralines with light spice notes from the rye.  Off dry but seems sweeter.  Excellent.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, burnt caramel, tar, light peat, light whiskey, roasting, rye, slight vanilla, slight raisin, slight oak, and hints of coconut and molasses.  Poured very dark brown/ruby in color with a small, creamy, dense, tan/beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, rye, slight salt, slight coconut, light whiskey, roasting, burnt caramel, slight tar, slight molasses, light vanilla, slight raisin, and slight tobacco.  Medium to full body.  Slick, smooth, then slightly dry and lightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, burnt caramel, light vanilla, finish is slightly dry.  10.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

22oz Bottle. Dark pour with tan head that fades fast but leaves nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, vanilla, oak, dark fruit, a hint of chocolate and a really nice balance of whiskey. Flavors of oak, dates, fig and light vanilla. The whiskey comes through but is not over powering. The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. I cant say how it stacks up to the beers it consists of but this is a pretty solid brew.

This one really gives way to the barrell and the whiskey in it. There is a little of the jewbelation chocolate flavour and some figginess too. In both the nose and the pallet there it a predomonamce of the barrell and then it fades  out into the whiskey. It helps to tame down some of the wilder jewbelation flavours but I wouldnt necessarily call it an improvement, more of a new interpretation.

Bottle 330 ml  
Aromasmoky malty with hints of whiskey , alcohol and brown sugars. Great refined aroma of strong ale. 9-
 Appearance  black brown with medium plus creamy top. Fragmental lace.
Flavor and Palate : Full bodied. creamy soft texture , light oak character , good malt feel with following light bitterness. Complex , very approachable compilation.

Deep chestnut color with a light head. Vanilla, booze, dark date like fruit, and perhaps roast caramel in the aroma. I hate to say that this is already a bit oxidized but it seems so. A bit of cardboard to the aroma and taste and it is destracting. Well integrated in every other way. Nicely blended vanilla, caramel, chocolate, wood and boozer/bourbon, with touches of dark fruit. Very nice as it continues to warm. Mild carbonation, creamy mouth feel.

Nice carbonation which contributes to the wonderful aroma. nutty - woody - dark fruit and whiskey. Smells great.

Appearance is perfect and a head that stays around

Taste is delicious. Perfect whisky flavor and balance - I could drink this rich treat all night.  not too sweet at all. In fact maybe a little dry on my palate.

Overall - glad I bought as much as I could - awesome beer - My favorite from hebrew.

Complex, strong, whiskey right there, some sourness.  Black with big lace.  Would have this again, but it is big, and noticeably boozy. jasons bottle. Above average mouthfeel.Whiskey and barreling come through in smell.

Tallahassee, Fl - Market Square Liquors - 22 oz bomber. Extremely dark edging to black pour with a thick khaki colored head that leave a nice coat of lacing. Fragrant aroma with lots of sweet goodness. Pick up some dates, molasses, bourbon. Flavor is solid and bold and leaning to the sweet side. Barrel aging is evident, with a nice whiskey presence in the back end. Front end has nice sweet molasses, hints of chocolate. some bourbon and a slight hint of licorice. Mouthfeel is thick and rich. Could be a muddled mess, but turned out well.
Draft at PP Carlsbads Barrel Blast.  Dark brown pour, light tan head.  Sweet caramel malts, fruit, chocolate, raisin, and whiskey.  Its fine, I am not very interested in trying it again though.

Bottle; poured a very dark brown or black.  Aroma of alcohol, caramel, whiskey, wood and a hint of cocoa.  Alot of cocoa in the flavor up front.  Cocoa then goes a bit to caramel and fruit.  Alcohol hidden.  Sweet, with a respectful use of the barrel.

Last bottle from the 8-14 vertical pack. Thin head sits on dark liquid. Aroma of thick dark malt and spice. Not sure I would pick out the rye whiskey element if I was not looking. Big dark malt flavour and thick mouth presence. Bigger alcohol kick in the finish with a lingering whiskey aftertaste. This is one beer big enough to really wrestle the barrel addition. Raises the beer to another level. I like it. Better than an average Jewbelation but not as good as a couple of peaks.

On tap at Bodega. 

A- Served headless in a 10oz flower vase. The beer is a perhaps a little lighter than I thought it was going to be. It certainly aligns itself with the brown hues. A little bit of raw honey coloration in the highlights. 

S- The aroma is very sweet, but Im not surprised. Each Jewbelation has some sort of fruit that has biblical significance, plus this is whiskey barreled. It is certainly figgy with a velvety vanilla underpinning. The whiskey adds some more mellow smoothness. The maltiness of the base blend is of the caramel order with toffee and nougat. 

T- This is a big beer, and lets you know it, but also doesnt beat your taste buds down. Its a big beer that lets you still feel tough. Whiskey and oak weave a basket of vanilla and spicy alcohol in which a caramel and dark fruit base is carried. The finish is sweet with fruits along the lines of wine grapes, figs, dates, plums, you know, King David food. 

D- Quite enjoyable. I would have no problem grabbing another vase of this before its gone.

tap at hopcat..pours a deep reddish brown with medium beige head..this beers is full of dark fruit, light chocolate, raisin, and whiskey...big resinous hops in the aroma and flavor...bitter finish..seems a bit over-the-top for my style, but interesting

Bouteille venant du sample pack 2010.
Couleur cuivre, brune foncée. Mousse est fine et beige.
Arôme ressort bien avec le whisky et se mélangeant au caramel et malt et cette combinaison domine le nez.

En bouche, le tonneau est de suite présent suivi de malt grillé, note caramel, fine vanille et pas mal de chaleur venant du whisky. Il semble que le profile de houblon que je notais dans les autres bières de la série se soit atténué avec cette mise en tonneau. Le whisky laisse en bouche ce mélange chêne et whisky qui reste frais en bouche, quasi mentholé.
Ma préférée de la série. Cest fou ce que une bière âgée en tonneau peu changer. Qcq notes épicées du bois, chocolat avec au fini une toute fine amertume.
Pours dark brown into a snifter. Mocha head recedes to hug rim. Oak aromas. Thick with raisin and plum from front to back with a hot lasting vanilla oak finish.

12oz bottle pours murky rutty mahogany with tan head. The aroma is sweet bourbon, some spicy oak, a light amount of dark roasted malts, dark fruity esters and dark chocolate all followed by a touch of heat at the end of the draw. The taste is sweet and fairly smooth bourbon and a healthy dose of vanilla. The palate gets a bit creamy as notes of dark roasted malts, molasses and some chocolate take this to about midway. Into the finish growing bourbon booziness and lingering sweet vanilla slide into the after taste. Nice brew that leans barrel forward.

12oz bottle from Jewbelation Vertical pack.
Pours deep and dark, a hint of ruby when held up to the light. Very full mocha head, nice retention.  The nose is luscious, the rye whisky notes blending with dark fruit, sweet chocolate and toffee malt, some bread and resiny hops.  The whisky doesnt dominate, which bodes well.  Medium body, lots of carbonation, very zippy.  Nice sweetness up front, malty midpalate, and finishing with some pleasant hop bitterness and rye whisky warmth.  Really well composed, a nice sipper and something that should be nice with some age.

Bottle.  Pours like Rod Carew..a black jew...and much like Rod Carew, this thing was sporting a huge jew fro...but this one was a lot lighter in color than Rods...almost like white russian-colored.  I bet Rod Carew wasnt a Russian Jew...but Im a Russian Jew. So it coo.  Nutty nose, with some touches of hops, but a lot of toffee going on in this one.  Actually, very vividly toffee-like, like heath bar..in fact, it smells damn good.  Flavors arent too shabby either...with lots of toffee and vanilla coming through from those barrels, I suppose.  For a hodge podge blend of too many random beers, this thing came together like a fine pair of legs around my head...Its just sweet enough to accent the lovely marriage of the malts and the barrel influence and nicely balanced with some unassuming but necessary bittering hops.  quite nice, actually.
bottle, thanks to jjfoodie,  dark brown with tan foam, aroma of datenut bread, flavor is sweet dark fruit, brown sugar and cognac

Bottle:   Deep cola, deep brown hues, thin whispy light beige head, sparce lacing.   Now that is a nice whiskey aroma!   Smells great!   Faint alcohol, wood, and burnt/dark chocolate.   Rich maltiness, smooth whiskey, a little prune and breadiness.   I was expecting a beer that was way overly malty, but this one is nice.   Warming, but not really alcoholic.   Underlying beer is a little difficult to discern because of the whiskey, but its malty enough to carry it through.   Simple, whiskey like, easy to put down, and the ABV is very well hidden.   Yeah, I would reach for another.   Oh, and its not heavy.   Moderate body and mouthfeel.   Enjoyable!

22 oz. bottle. Batch 002 with 892 cases. Bottled on 12/1/2010. Pours a thick tiny bubbled beige head, of long duration, with attractive lacing, over a clear reddish browm (SRM 35) body.....nose is (in no particular order) molasses, plum/prune, raisin, beef, soy sauce, raisin, dried cherry, vanilla....taste is sweet throughout with dried cherry, raisin, light beef, light Marmite, finishing with light vanilla, touch of whiskey and lingering terpenes.....mouth feel is thick, heavy, sticky, chewy, carbonation low. This is a huge beer. It is remarkably well balanced, considering the malt, hop and alcohol forces brought to bear. But, then again, it was a beer done as a Solera.  The complexity is extreme and this NEEDS to age to meet its full potential. BJCP 8/3/15/4/7

12 oz. bottle as part of the Vertical Jewbelation gift pack (2010) purchased at Grape & Gourmet.  Pours dark brown with a foamy khaki head.  Aroma of whiskey, toffee, vanilla, and sweet malts.  Incredible flavor from the whiskey barrels with hints of cinnamon and clove and floral hops.  You can almost tell that this is a blend of Jewbelations 8-14 blended in whiskey barrels even if the bottle didnt say so.  The combination of these beers is near perfect.  Very well done.

Pour is a deep deep red color, nearly black. Nose is of dark fruits with some vanilla notes, as well as oak presence. Taste is similar to all of the other jewbelations with a bit more of a mellow vanilla presence.
sticky sweet rye caramel malt bomb. chewy and sticky festivus rum balls with a bitter hop profile. like chewing grass and chocolate mint and weeds. and caramel rum cookies. yes.

Bottle pours black with tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit and sherry like vanilla notes.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is vanilla, figs, raisin, plum, only a touch of booze, and finishes semi-sweet with sherry like flavors.  Very nice.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a fair amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2011 The best Jewbelation by a stretch with a syrupy body and esters of chocolate, coffee, smoke, figs, dates, prunes, plums, spices, toffee, anda hefty underpinning of Sazerac which helps to dry out the finish a tad.

A real sipper,and a genuine pleasure.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 Bomber from Keils. Deep dark ruby in color. Nice whiskey nose with a little bit of fruitiness. Whiskey and roasted malt up front. Some woody notes Smooth bodied. Lots of rich malts and coffee. A hint of alcohol.
tap at barcade - dark sweet molasses brown sugar, raisins, and caramel candy. Tasty, though some conflicting flavors.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark deep mahogany brown with a dense tan head and no lacing.  Rigt away, the room fills with big raisin and prune notes soaked in whiskey and brown sugar.  As it sits, warms and opens up things mellow and meld together a bit more and lend way to smooth caramel notes with some bourbony leather and wet wood notes, withe the sweetness being the driving force.  Nice smooth mouthfeel with ample body and carb.  Malty sweet dark dried fruit and caramel sweetness.  Move into carb that opens up some bitterness then makes way for vanilla, leather and tobacco more caramel maltiness then quite a bit of wet barrel notes lingering on the middle to back of my toungue.

Bottle... Very dark mahogany ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Decent retention. The aroma is a lavish indulgence of caramel, oak, maple syrup and chocolate with just enough rye whiskey to enhance rather than detract. Full-bodied and oily with mild carbonation. The flavor is mainly of caramel and toffee with tannic hop bitterness and a hint of rye whiskey. Moderately bitter, warming, wholesome finish.

12 oz. bottle from Wine and Cheese Place as part of the Vertical Jewbelation gift set.  Pours a deep, dark cola brown with a small tan head, just like all the others.  Aroma of vanilla, oak, roasted malts, bourbon, chocolate, brown sugar, and a hint of dark fruit.  Gets better as it warms.  Flavor of vanilla, oak, bourbon, brown sugar, caramel malts, and bitter earth.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a boozy mouthfeel.  Lingering hot alcoholic finish.  I thought this would be even sweeter than the 14, but I guess the rest of them mellow it out in the blend.  A fitting final beer to the series.
aroma....bourbon, coconut, vanilla dream.  It is duplicated in flavor. Palate is sexy smooth soft and luxurious. So so good. Over the top!

22 oz. bottle from the QFC in Capitol Spill. I meant Hill, Capitol Hill. Black opaque body with a head that disappears quite quickly. Nice, sweet vanilla whiskey aroma. Im not getting much out of the aroma other than the aforementioned aromas. Nice subtle whiskey and vanilla aroma. Its very straightforward. A little bit of heat comes from the booze, but not much. Bits of chocolate and roast poke through. This is a delightful beer to be drinking. Im usually quite happy with the Jewbelation beers, and this is no exception. Unexpectedly, Im getting bits of coconut, as well. Great brew, with a little too much heat.

Bottle from the Chanukah pack. Smells of raisins, maple, chocolate and vanilla. Dark purplish color with little head. Tastes of carmel, figs and whiskey on the aftertaste. Most of the Chanukah beers in the pack have tasted similar and got less drinkable as the ABV increased. This one, however, was probably one of my favorites. Not sure if it was because it was the last one, but Id buy it again to see.

12oz bottle 12/31/10 (Vertical Pack)-48° in Snifter-Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits, and whiskey. Taste of the same with dark fruit becoming more prominent. This full bodied brew is very tasty. Wish there was more whiskey taste but still tasty.

22oz bottle. was expecting a bit more from this for some reason, but this is proof that its not really more than the sum of its parts to mix all these together. thats all there is to be said really. any of the regulars on their own are better than this one for a fraction of the price.

Thanks to jjfoodie and yelof77 for sharing this bottle. I am a big fan of the other Jewbelation beers so I have high hopes for this one.

The beer pours a dark brownish-red color with a tan head. The aroma is heavy on the rye whiskey, but I also get a lot of cherries, maple, oak and vanilla. A very inviting aroma. 

The flavor is heavy on the brown sugar, rye whiskey, maple and roasted malt. The alcohol, as it is in most Jewbelation beers, is present. That being said, it goes very well with the other flavors and doesnt hurt the drinkability in any way. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very drinkable for a beer that is 10.5 percent alcohol. A great beer that didnt disappoint.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of JJFoodie)  Pours a mahogany body with a small tan head.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, vinous, oak, coconut, raisins, and vanilla.  Flavor of cherry, vinous, caramel, roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, whiskey, raisins, and toasted coconut.

12 oz bottle in the vertical gift pack.  pours a light black with a 1/4" tan head.... settles down to nothing.  whiskey nose - not in your face as some other barrel aged beers - but could stand out a bit more for me.  some wood, leather and sweet sugars as well.  big round body with vanilla hitting the senses right away... some deeper wood notes flow down the sides of the mouth with the whiskey settling in the back.  some dark fruits notes seep out a bit.  sweeter finish with a whiskey aftertaste.  this is very well done - extremely smooth and balanced.

Bottle courtesy jjfoodie. Clear dark rouge color with a light ring of tan head. Aroma is dark malts, heavy grain and lots of sugary syrup. Flavor is spicy sweet, cologne, dark sugar and caramel malts. Fantastic finish. Very nice.
a little drunk when i drank this one last night. palate was a little jacked coming straight off a bells expedition stout. whiskey was tastefully done and not over the top.

Batch 2. Pours black, with a dense tan head, and that old familiar red tinge when held to light. Pretty. Holy moly this smells delicious - the rye really added an earthy quality that it was missing before - Jewbelation is normally a very, very sweet brew... and this version is reeled in with a better balance and greater complexity. Raisins and figs blend with dark chocolate, toasted malts, some candi sugar, oak, and a bunch of vanilla. This puppy doesnt disappoint. All of those notes come through in the flavor, and its just effervescent enough to keep it from being sticky in your mouth. The rye is there, but not at all overpowering, and this seems the perfect blend of all of these brews. Im really, really impressed - absolutely worth the money. Heres hoping they make a habit of this blend, now that the series is approaching impossible recipes (15%, 15 kinds of hops and malts). Fantastic.

Part of HeBrew Jewbelation Vertical Pack - $25.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours an essentially black body with an initial tall, airy, beige head which eventually settles into a thinnish layering.

Smell: Earthy, barrel-licked, lightly sweetish nose with well-integrated notes smelling dark caramel, humble chocolate, moistened previously dried fruits, and carefully charred oak barrels.

Taste: Smooth, sweet caramel and sugary milk chocolate with additional sweet additions of brown sugar sliding effortlessly into coconut-vanilla cake and piquant oak with a carefully dosed dash of whiskey. Hints of coffee and oven-burnt pumpernickel bread crusts. Slight wooden and earthen tones. Not much bitterness felt, really, or heated booze for that matter. Rye spiciness from the malts utilized as well as the Sazerac barrel as well as the hops used. Sweetish, oak-aged finish with a pleasing smoothness to it.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Features that pleasant smoothness found throughout the majority of the HeBrew anniversary beers.

Drinkability: After the particularly potent Jewbelation 14, Im surprised (and pleased) by the relative smoothness of this brew. Very enjoyable, and, now that I hear its available in bombers, besides the task of just hunting down another gift box, I may grab another bottle to quietly age.

Sampled on tap at 1702, Tucson; December 2010
The beer arrives from the tap, in its special Jewbelation Vertical glass, with an opaque, concentrated amber color that is topped by a frothy, ½-finger thick, dark amber tinged tanned head.  The beer shows a touch of clear, deep red / brown hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of vanilla soaked toasted coconut, softly spicy oak, Bourbon, some toasted malt character that has a richly concentrated caramel character to it.  The aroma is appetizing and well integrated, though not entirely unsurprising.

Soft and creamy feeling, the flavor accentuates this as does the light carbonation.  Nice flavors of vanilla and coconut infuse the tongue and palate along with sweet, concentrated, caramelized malt character that plays more of supporting role than being intrinsically being noticeable in and of itself.  The beer finishes with some spicy and hot alcohol notes that are subdued enough to not get annoying as well as a sort of tartness that I associated with charred oak and Bourbon.  There is perhaps a touch of almost roasted malt character to this beer that helps to dry out the overall effect of this beer.  This has a fullness to it, enough to coat the palate and provide a creamy texture, that balances the barrel character quite well; this is definitely a sipping beer, though it is not cloying as it has enough barrel influenced spiciness, toasty malt character and alcoholic warming to keep this fairly well balanced.  At times this seems to remind me a bit of some sort of richly caramelized mix of soda and ice-cream; it is more the feeling of this than any particular flavors, perhaps it is the texture that has evoked these.

This is a pretty nice barrel aged brew, while the Whiskey / barrel character is dominant, it is smooth enough to not become overwhelming and the rich, chewy malt character certainly helps with this as well.  And I always like when a barrel aged brew is able to achieve the vanilla and toasted coconut character that this beer manages to achieve.  This ends up being a very nice cap to my long, working lunch.
Draft.  Pours a mahogany body with an off white head and okay lacing.  Malty sweet medicinal cherry, and whiskey tones.  Faded hop notes, very vinous, apricots.  Sweet and warm, average.

The aroma is very boozy with roasted malts, caramel, molasses, dark fruit, whisky, oak, hops, mincemeat, and chocolate. The appearance is dark red brown with a tan head. The taste is like the aroma with a warming aftertaste. The palate is smooth. Overall an interesting beer that is worth a try if you can get one but not outstanding.
very strong and flavorful, lots of dark fruits with figs, dates and prunes. very sweet and strong. little bitterness but lot sof character. slightly wooden.

Draft at Rattle n Hum. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Oaky aroma with some light malts sweetness. The flavor has oak and whiskey with some malty sweetness and floral hops. The barrel gives a nice dimension to an otherwise average line of beers.

Bottle.  A dark brown color with a light brown head.  A strong dark fruity (dates and raisins), maple, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, and toffee aroma.  Smooth and rich on the palate, delightfully warming. Rich and full of character. I appreciated the understated nature of the  whiskey barrel aging.  It was just right.
Its very, very sweet. Big and malty. Black in color. The 10% alcohol is apparent.

Tap @ Barcade.
Dark brown and clear with some tan head. Aroma is caramel, malt, sweet, dark fruit, light toast, smoke, bit of spice. Taste is a bit chaotic with some malt sweetness up front and a bit of hop bitterness and light spiciness. Interesting but a bit much going on.

Poured a very dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of wood, vanilla, dark fruits, and molasses.  Flavor is quite complex with wood, vanilla, fruit, caramel, and some bourbon-like flavors.  Great balance and complexity.  The alcohol was well hidden and it wasnt too overpowering.

Tap at Holiday Ale Festival. Dark brown pour, small tan head. Smelt of rye, dark fruit, cherries, vanilla and some light chocolate. Flavors were brilliant with some upfront chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit and some finishing rye and roast. Absolutely delicious beer, I had multiple samples.

12 oz. bottle, as part of the Jewbelation 8-pack, pours dark with a tan head. Oaky aroma, with vanilla, molasses and dark fruits. Flavour of caramel, oak, vanilla, molasses and wood. The rye finishes it off, with a slightly bitter and alcoholic finish. This seems more like an experiment that came out to whatever it was rather than something uniquely crafted. That said, it is great.

On draught @ Taco Mac Crabapple.  Black pour with a small beige head, very lacy.  Aroma was of slight sweet malt, subtle bourbon and some wood.  Silky smooth mouth, light carbonation.  Bourbon came through nicely without being overpowering.  This was almost stout like, not roasty but big dark malts with sweet bourbon all over it.  Extremely nice indeed.

Day 8.  Mazel tov!  Super dark caramel, nearly black, sticky sandy head.  Nice rye barrel nose, soft, though it covers the rest of the beer.  Dark wood, sugary caramel, concentrated grain, heavy, though lifted up from the wood.  Little buggy in the finish I think.

Bottle pured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of rye whiskey, oak, carmel, dates, raisin and light brown sugar. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of rye whiskey, oak, toffee, carmel, dates, fig and light vanilla with a smooth lingering rye whiskey finish.
Tap at Churchkey, courtesy of Darren - thank you sir!  Tastes like a cross between pumpernickel bread and Christmas fruitcake - nice!

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Dark brown with low, lasting tan foam. Very strong raspberry, tartaric, winy aroma, with some more subtle, interesting bits like smoke, violet, and cider. Flavor is quite sweet and roasty with generous round caramelly bourbon, but there is also a non-negligible swampy component that reminds me of spit on a hot lightbulb, and none of that appealing tartness in the nose gets carried through in the flavor. Drinkably restrained but warmingly big, this is one of the most interesting beers Ive ever tasted.

This was the highlight of the vertical tasting pack for me. Really dark pour with small head. lots of oak, burnt toast and alochol present in the aroma. Taste was tons of oak, vanilla, whiskey, alcohol. Overall really good.

Draft.  Large, creamy milkshakish beige head atop opaque cola black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, rye whiskey, some vanilla, cognac, light chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, vanilla, whiskey, some cognac, chocolate.  Smooth medium-full body, some creaminess.

Bottle from the Hannukah sampler pack, from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a thin fizzy brown head that fades quickly to the edges. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, brown sugar, grapes, berries, citrus, some toastiness. There is a bit of a metallic note to the hops that is a bit offputting. The taste is chocolate, toffee, soy, bitter hops, citrus and other fruity notes, nuts, grapes, more bitter hops in the finish. Medium-full bodied. Nice beer.

Tap @ Holiday Ale Festival...  Poured a deep brown with a khaki head.  A bit of hops on the nose, lactose, and sugary malts.  Sweet with cocoa, rye, toffee, and toasted oak and whiskey.  Roast and grains and a bit boozy.
Black with a creamy off white head.  Chocolate and whiskey aroma.  Tastes of chocolate, candy, whiskey, oak, vanilla, and citrus.  Very good.
Tap at Redlight. Dark copper brown pour. Huge barrel, whiskey aroma, toffee, aroma. Dark fruit taste, oakiness, toffee, thick and creamy. Really nice.

Draft at Redlight Redlight, consumed right after having the vertical 8-14 flight.  The body is a clear, dark, reddish-mahogany color, and it supports a small head of mocha foam.  Small rings of lacing mark the glass.  Rye whiskey immediately infiltrates the nose, bringing notes of caramelized sugars, lightly charred, oaky vanilla, and a hint of peanut skins.  Underlying that is singed caramel and stewed dark fruit, primarily fig.  Flavors offer a surprising dose of dry roast, suggesting some chocolate and a touch of coffee, though sweeter caramel and residual fruity sugars rush in to re-claim dominance.  Figs and raisins, a common theme in this series, are prominent.  The rye serves as a nice, warming accompaniment, rich with oak and hinting at carraway.  The palate, as logic would dictate, falls somewhere between the 11 and the 12 in terms of sugary heft, thinned a bit perhaps by the rye barrel.  Consistently moderate in carbonation, the body goes down easy and finishes warm and woody.  Good brew.  I like this blend quite a bit.  Nice to try the entire vertical in one sitting.

12oz. bottle from the Vertical Jewbelation Hanukkah pack.  Pours out black as sin under a fluffy tan head, only some lacing.  Aroma is temptingly sweet, with hints of molasses, wood, rum soaked raisins, and lots of chocolate.  Definitely smells like a sippin beer, some boozy notes.  Taste hits exactly like a barrel aged stout would.  Hard to beleive this is a "American Strong Ale".  Everything about the look/smell/taste screams Imperial Stout.  Anyhow, the flavor hits with lots of wood barrel rum (or whiskey), chocolate, molasses, black licorice, a hint of plum, ends in more wood and booze.  Somewhat messy flavor profile and texture.  If you love boozy wood-aged beers, this is fine and well.  But this one doesnt do it for me, exactly.  Too heavy and boozy.  Its trying too hard.  Not terrible though.  Mixed feelings I suppose.
12oz bottle from vertical pack.  deep brown under a small tan head.  aroma of whiskey.  flavors of dark fruits with bit of tartness from the barrel more so than chocolate malts.

The final brew in a 9 beer amazing Jewish-based vertical. It is dark brown on the pour with a crimson hue and small head. The aroma is light, soft boozy whiskey notes. It tastes smooth with notes of soy, sweet malts, and soft booze.

Sampled at fobab 2010. Pours deep brown with a creamy light tan head. Aroma is rich malty, dark fruit and a burnt toast malt candy character. Flavor is much the same, very malty sweet and candyish. Some vanilla and oaky notes come into play with a touch of chocolate. A bit fruity and woody lingering notes. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Hmmmmm I like them individually better, too muddled overall.

12oz bottle.  Sweet malty nose w/ hints of heavy booze thoughout. Deep rich brown topped w/ a baby khaki head. Sweet malts mix w/ rye & wood. Great balance & somuchmorethan a combination of the series; a different beer.

12oz bottle from the Vertical Jewbelation pack, poured into a Snifter at 42°.  Color is black with good carbonation and a small tan head.  Aroma of oak and brown sugar.  Full bodied with a sharp mouth feel.  Flavor jumps out sweet with some dark fruit, vanilla and oak then just a hint of coffee and ends with a bitter bite.  In the after taste the bitterness fades out leaving a whiskey taste lingering.   Overall its not as good as the other Jewbelation brews, although its a complex brew it all comes across a little too sharp.  It may be better after it ages a bit and smoothes out.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of moderate coconut, vanilla, whiskey, light chocolate, molasses, alcohol, and a touch of dark fruits.  It pours a dark brown with no transparency and a three finger beige head that lasts a minute or so before fading to a thick film.  Theres some spotty lacing left behind.  The flavor starts with grape, cola, and some tangy fruitiness.  The finish has notes of chocolate, vanilla, molasses, charred oak, light spiciness, whiskey, and faint pine.  Theres no alcohol in the flavor.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a soft creamy mouthfeel.   
Overall, the vertical pack started off pretty decent with Eight and Nine.  Initially I thought it peaked at Ten and Eleven.  Twelve was definitely the low point for me.  Thirteen and Fourteen were nice rebounds...and they saved the best for last with the barrel-aged Vertical Jewbelation.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2010 On draft at Brick Store Pub in decatur.  Pours a clear brown with chestnut brown highlights and great sticky light brown head.  Nice sweet purple grape, and raisins and soy sauce and just amazing. Very rarely do I ever drink order more than one glass of the same beer at a bar, but this one was my order for the rest of the evening.  More notes of tobacco, and butterscotch came out later in the night. HOLY HELL.... This is amazing.

Bottle (Batch 001 of 230 cases, bottled on 10/4/2010). Pours with a deep brown, near black body with a khaki tan head that fades much quicker than any of the other (non-barrel aged) Jewbelations. Aromas of dry rye whiskey, tons of dark fruit, tobacco, oak, vanilla, dusty and spicy. Caramel and molasses. (Side thought...this thing has 77 "different" malts in it, not including the malt in the rye whiskey...hmm...).  (on another note, shouldnt this be at least 11%, if not more? If it is a straight blend of the beers it should be 11% before any barrel aging. Apparently there is a heavy reliance on 8 and 9 in this blend). There is some familiar smell (not altogether pleasant) that I am picking up. I cannot place it though. Popcorn maybe? Flavors of rye whiskey, oak, and dark fruit. Beyond that I cannot pick out much else. A sheer melee of flavors. Some cotton candy and cola notes. Creamy carbonation. Big mouthfeel, lingering tannins. An interesting concept, but the actual beer ends up a bit muddled. The reason why I rate it highly is that there is nothing technically wrong with the flavors, and I am a sucker for barrel aged beers.

11/8/10.  12oz bottle from the vertical beer.  Brown pour with reds under a fizzy off-white head that turns to a film quick.  Sweet brown sugar and dark fruit aroma with plenty of coconut and vanilla - its like a BA barleywine.  Surprisingly bitter flavor, the whiskey coming through much more in the flavor straight-up insteaf of subtle.  Also sweet and sugary at the same time... and grape juice.  Hmmm.
On tap at Redlight. Dark brown-ruby pour with a thin light tan head. Spiced caramel aroma with heavy malts and dark fruit. Moderate fruitcake flavor, some alcohol, nice brew.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Lovely rye whiskey on the nose, very excited Sazerac is one my favorite ryes, with hints of smoke and molasses.  Pours dark brown almost black with a thick tan head.  Smooth oak and spicy rye notes with molasses and vanilla with some piney hops and tobacco, very rich and smooth.  Awesome.
